factoid: The infantry that had been among the bushes in front of the battery and along the Kámenka streamlet retreated at ten o’clock.
The infantry had been among the bushes in front of the battery.
The infantry had been along the Kámenka streamlet.
From the battery the infantry could be seen running back past the battery carrying their wounded on their muskets.
A general with his suite came to the battery.
The general spoke to the colonel.
The general gave Pierre an angry look.
The general ordered the infantry supports behind the battery to lie down so as to be less exposed to fire.
The infantry supports behind the battery lay down to be less exposed to fire.
From amid the ranks of infantry to the right of the battery came the sound of a drum and shouts of command.
From the battery an observer saw those ranks of infantry move forward.
Pierre looked over the wall of the trench.
Pierre was particularly struck by a pale young officer.
The pale young officer let his sword hang down.
The pale young officer was walking backwards.
The pale young officer kept glancing uneasily around.
The ranks of the infantry disappeared amid the smoke.
The long‑drawn shout of the infantry could still be heard.
The rapid musketry firing of the infantry could still be heard.
Crowds of wounded men and stretcher‑bearers came back from that direction a few minutes later.
Projectiles began to fall more frequently in the battery.
Several men were lying about who had not been removed.
Around the cannon the men moved briskly and busily.
No one took notice of Pierre.
Pierre was shouted at once or twice for being in the way.
The senior officer moved with big, rapid strides from one gun to another.
The senior officer had a frowning face.
The young officer had a face that was more flushed.
The young officer commanded the men more scrupulously than ever.
The soldiers handed up the charges.
The soldiers turned.
The soldiers loaded.
The soldiers did their business with strained smartness.
The soldiers gave little jumps as they walked.
The soldiers walked as though they were on springs.
The stormcloud had come upon them.
The fire that Pierre had watched kindle burned up brightly in every face.
Pierre stood beside the commanding officer.
The young officer ran up to his superior with his hand on his shako.
The young officer said, "I have the honor to report, sir, that only eight rounds are left."
The young officer asked, "Are we to continue firing?"
The senior shouted, "Grapeshot!".
The senior looked over the wall of the trench.
The senior did not answer the young officer’s question.
The young officer gave a gasp.
The young officer bent double and sat down on the ground like a bird shot on the wing.
Everything became strange, confused, and misty in Pierre’s eyes.
One cannon ball whistled by and struck the earthwork.
One cannon ball whistled by and struck a soldier.
One cannon ball whistled by and struck a gun.
Pierre had not noticed these sounds before.
Pierre now heard nothing else.
On the right of the battery soldiers shouting "Hurrah!" were running backwards.
It seemed to Pierre that they were running backwards.
A cannon ball struck the very end of the earthwork by which Pierre was standing.
The cannon ball crumbled down the earth.
A black ball flashed before Pierre’s eyes.
At the same instant the black ball plumped into something.
Some militiamen who were entering the battery ran back.
The officer shouted, "All with grapeshot!"
The sergeant ran up to the officer.
The sergeant informed the officer in a frightened whisper that there were no more charges.
The officer shouted, "The scoundrels! What are they doing?"
The officer turned to Pierre.
The officer’s face was red.
The officer was perspiring.
The officer’s eyes glittered under his frowning brow.
The officer yelled, "Run to the reserves and bring up the ammunition boxes!"
The officer avoided Pierre with his eyes.
The officer spoke to his men.
Pierre said, "I’ll go."
The officer strode across to the opposite side.
The officer did not answer Pierre.
The officer shouted, "Don’t fire… Wait!"
The man who had been ordered to go for ammunition stumbled against Pierre.
The man said, "Eh, sir, this is no place for you."
The man ran down the slope.
Pierre ran after the man.
Pierre avoided the spot where the young officer was sitting.
One cannon ball flew over Pierre.
Another cannon ball flew over Pierre.
A third cannon ball flew over Pierre.
The cannon balls fell in front of Pierre.
The cannon balls fell beside Pierre.
The cannon balls fell behind Pierre.
Pierre ran down the slope.
Pierre asked himself, "Where am I going?"
Pierre was already near the green ammunition wagons.
Pierre halted irresolutely.
Pierre did not know whether to return or go on.
A terrible concussion threw Pierre backwards to the ground.
Pierre was dazzled by a great flash of flame.
A deafening roar, crackling, and whistling made Pierre’s ears tingle.
Pierre was sitting on the ground leaning on his hands.
The ammunition wagons Pierre had been approaching no longer existed.
Only charred green boards and rags littered the scorched grass.
A horse galloped past with fragments of its shaft dangling behind it.
Another horse lay on the ground like Pierre.
The horse lay on the ground uttering prolonged and piercing cries.
